content.raw:
I think you have the correct joint axes for all joints except the right usy, but I will check out those others. The USY joint is atypical because it does not lie along any cardinal axis.

I think you have it right that motion along any **x or **z joint of opposite signs will achieve a symmetric pose. Similarly since we defined the first shoulder joint as a y joint, we want motion of similar sign to achieve a symmetric pose.

I think my poor drawing should clear up our convention for the handedness of the joints.  Red arrows indicate an **x joint, and green a **y.
content.html:
I think you have the correct joint axes for all joints except the right usy, but I will check out those others. The USY joint is atypical because it does not lie along any cardinal axis.

I think you have it right that motion along any x or z joint of opposite signs will achieve a symmetric pose. Similarly since we defined the first shoulder joint as a y joint, we want motion of similar sign to achieve a symmetric pose.

I think my poor drawing should clear up our convention for the handedness of the joints. Red arrows indicate an x joint, and green a y.
